definition.goal: Create an RSS Feed from scratch that I can use on multiple sites

requirements.explanation: An RSS feed requires several XML tags and their attributes. See 'tags' for a description of required tags.
tags: Give the URL of the website linked to the feed.
Offer a short summary of the feed's content.
Contain each piece of content in the feed.
Show when the content was published.
Give a unique ID for each content item.
requirements.example:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?>
<rss version="2.0">

<channel>
  <title>W3Schools Home Page</title>
  <link>https://www.w3schools.com</link>
  <description>Free web building tutorials</description>
  <item>
    <title>RSS Tutorial</title>
    <link>https://www.w3schools.com/xml/xml_rss.asp</link>
    <description>New RSS tutorial on W3Schools</description>
  </item>
  <item>
    <title>XML Tutorial</title>
    <link>https://www.w3schools.com/xml</link>
    <description>New XML tutorial on W3Schools</description>
  </item>
</channel>

</rss>

snapshots.summary: This project focuses on creating a standards-compliant RSS feed from scratch. RSS (Really Simple Syndication) is an XML-based format that allows websites to share content updates with subscribers. The feed must include essential XML tags such as the RSS version, channel metadata (title, link, description), and items with their own metadata (title, link, description, publication date, and unique ID). The goal is to develop a flexible RSS structure that can be implemented across multiple websites while maintaining proper syntax and adherence to RSS 2.0 standards.

snapshots.summary: We've established the fundamental structure of an RSS feed, including required XML tags (XML declaration, RSS element, channel metadata, and item elements) and their proper nesting. We've covered the purpose of each tag and viewed a complete example of a basic RSS 2.0 feed structure. Now we're preparing to create a Node.js script that can automatically generate a valid RSS feed by scanning local HTML files, extracting the necessary metadata (titles, URLs, descriptions, publication dates), and outputting a properly formatted XML document that follows RSS 2.0 standards.
